educational_objective: Diagnose pulmonary edema using point-of-care ultrasonography.
question_text: A patient is evaluated for dyspnea. Focused ultrasonography of the lung is performed.(Note that there is no sound for this video.)
question_stem: Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis based on the ultrasound findings?
critique: This ultrasound video shows findings consistent with pulmonary edema (Option C). It demonstrates vertical hyperechoic lines extending downward from the pleural line, similar to lasers or searchlights, known as B lines.Analogous to Kerley B lines on a chest radiograph, a diffuse B-line pattern suggests interstitial thickening, most often caused by fluid or pulmonary edema. This ultrasound also depicts a hyperechoic (bright white) horizontal line in the near field moving with respiration (“lung sliding”), which is a normal finding. Lung sliding and a B-line pattern throughout exclude pneumothorax. Similarly, a pleural effusion most often appears as an anechoic (black) region in dependent areas cephalad to the diaphragm.
